details.title: New Insights Into the BDD-Based Reliability Analysis of Phased-Mission Systems
details.standardTitle: New Insights Into the BDD-Based Reliability Analysis of Phased-Mission Systems

p: Yuchang Mo received the B. S. (2002), M.S. (2004), and Ph.D. (2008) degrees in Computer Science from Harbin Institute of Technology, China. From 2008 to May 2009, he worked at the School of Computer Science and Engineering in Southeast University. Dr. Mo is currently a Lecturer at the College of Mathematics, Physics, and Information Engineering, at Zhejiang Normal University, China. His research interests include computer system dependability evaluation, and computer system virtualization management.

authors.affiliation: Coll. of Math., Phys. & Inf. Eng., Zhejiang Normal Univ., Jinhua, China
authors.name: Yuchang Mo

details.abstract: We present a generalized analysis methodology for binary decision diagram-based fault tree analysis of a wide range of phased-mission systems, with various mission requirements, and structure characteristics. This methodology includes 1) four alternative variable ordering schemes: forward/backward phased dependent operations, and forward/backward concatenation; 2) a strategy to choose an adequate ordering scheme to process a new phased-mission system instance depending on its phase and mission configuration; and 3) efficient generation and evaluation algorithms for generalized phased-mission system binary decision diagrams adopting any arbitrary ordering scheme. The advantages of this methodology are in the low computational complexity, broad applicability, and easy implementation.

citations.title: New Insights Into the BDD-Based Reliability Analysis of Phased-Mission Systems

context.text: Reference [1] presents an approach to deal with the dependencies across the phases by using a set of \$s\$-independent mini-components to replace the component in each phase.

For conventional phase-OR PMS, [1] presents two variable ordering schemes (forward PDO, and backward PDO), which must abide by this rule: orderings of variables that belong to the same component, but to different phases, stay together.

In [1], the backward PDO scheme is a preferred choice because it is found that the size of the BDD generated by backward PDO is smaller than that generated by forward PDO based on the analysis results of some PMS instance.

But reference [1] does not use various PMS instances to show that the backward PDO is always good, especially when the combinatorial phase requirements (CPR) is considered, i.e., the practical PMS could have a failure criterion as any logical combination of the phase failures in terms of phase-AND, phase-K/M, and phase-OR.

references.text: J. D. Esary, H. Ziehms, "Reliability analysis of phased missions", Proc. Conf. Reliability and Fault Tree Analysis, pp. 213-236, 1975.

context.text: Reference [2] proposes a method based on the sum of disjoint products (SDP) to address such dependencies, but it usually needs to find the minimal cut sets, and calculate the SDP, which is still computationally intensive.

An algorithm for reliability
analysis of phased-mission systems
references.text: Y. Ma, K. S. Trivedi, "An algorithm for reliability analysis of phased-mission systems", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 2, no. 66, pp. 157-170, 1999.

links.abstract: This paper presents a new algorithm (PMS-BDD) based on the binary decision diagram (BDD) for reliability analysis of phased-mission systems (PMS). PMS-BDD uses phase algebra to deal with the dependence across the phases, and a new BDD operation to incorporate the phase algebra. Due to the nature of the BDD, cancellation of common components among the phases can be combined with the BDD generation, without additional operations; and the sum of disjoint products (SDP) can be implicitly represented...

context.text: Over the past decade, researchers have proposed a set of new algorithms based on binary decision diagrams (BDD) for fault tree analysis of a wide range of PMS with various mission requirements, and failure behaviors [3]–[8].

The experiments in [3] show that BDD-based algorithm, Phased Dependent Operation (PDO), is more efficient than the SDP-based algorithm, Ma & Trivedi (MT) algorithm, in both computation time, and storage space.

However, when variable orderings are concatenation orderings or other more arbitrary orderings, the generation and evaluation algorithms in [3] cannot produce correct PMS BDD, or system unreliability.
Reference [3] presents a benchmark with 1) 7 groups of components, each having \$n\$ components; 2) 5 system configurations; and 3) 4 mission configurations.
In [3], two PDO ordering schemes (forward PDO, and backward PDO) are presented.
In [3], the authors present an efficient PMS BDD generation algorithm called PDO.
Their evaluation is comparatively simple because these dependent variables can be processed together [3].
Because the ordering schemes and BDD generation algorithms developed in [3], [5] are widely used in the research work on generalized PMS, our results can also be integrated into new research work.

references.title:
A BDD-based algorithm for reliability analysis

references.text: X. Zang, H. Sun, K. S. Trivedi, "A BDD-based algorithm for reliability analysis of phased-mission systems", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 48, no. 1, pp. 50-60, 1999.

links.abstract: This paper proposes a generalized phased-mission system (GPMS) analysis methodology called GPMS-CPR that has high computation efficiency and is easy to implement. GPMS-CPR can evaluate a wider range of more practical systems with less restrictive mission requirements, while offering more human-friendly performance indices such as multilevel grading as compared to the previous PMS approaches. GPMS-CPR also accounts for imperfect coverage. This method implements an exciting synthesis of several ap...

context.text: Over the past decade, researchers have proposed a set of new algorithms based on binary decision diagrams (BDD) for fault tree analysis of a wide range of PMS with various mission requirements, and failure behaviors [3]–[4][8].
On the other hand, in the following research work [4], where the CPR is under consideration, backward PDO ordering is unconditionally accepted without more performance analysis.

When the backward PDO scheme (which is the preferred scheme in most related work [4]–[8]) is adopted, a special BDD operation can be used to deal with all the dependencies across the phases during the PMS BDD generation, and the PMS BDD evaluation is simple because all dependent variables are placed together.

Within this paper, consider the PMS that have the following assumptions: 1) component failures are \$s\$-independent within each phase; 2) a component remains down for the remaining phases if it is down in one phase, i.e., the system is not maintained, and 3) PMS may have combinatorial phase requirements (CPR) [4].

In this section, we try to show that the ordering schemes BPDO and FPDO have different performance for the PMS with different phase combinational logic, which is not identified by any related work [4]–[8].

references.title:
Analysis of generalized phased-mission
system reliability, performance, and sensitivity
references.text: L. Xing, J. B. Dugan, "Analysis of generalized phased-mission system reliability performance and sensitivity", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 51, no. 2, pp. 199-211, 2002.

links.abstract: This paper discusses some of the difficulties in the paper: "A BDD-based algorithm for reliability analysis of phased-mission systems" by X. Zang, H. Sun, and K. S. Trivedi.

context.text: Over the past decade, researchers have proposed a set of new algorithms based on binary decision diagrams (BDD) for fault tree analysis of a wide range of PMS with various mission requirements, and failure behaviors [3]–[5][8].
Reference [5] is the first research work to be conscious that forward PDO and backward PDO are just two possible ordering schemes, and many other arbitrary ordering schemes can also be used.

When the backward PDO scheme (which is the preferred scheme in most related work [4]–[5][8]) is adopted, a special BDD operation can be used to deal with all the dependencies across the phases during the PMS BDD generation, and the PMS BDD evaluation is simple because all dependent variables are placed together.
To allow concatenation ordering or other arbitrary ordering to be used, a two-phase generation algorithm is presented in [5].

A generalized PMS BDD generation algorithm, which can make use of concatenation ordering schemes, or other arbitrary ordering schemes, and make significant savings in the amount of storage and computation-time needed compared with the two-phase algorithm in [5].

Section VI proposes a generalized PMS BDD generation algorithm, which can make use of concatenation ordering schemes, or other arbitrary ordering schemes; and the performance comparison between our new algorithm, and the two-phase algorithm in [5].

In this section, we try to show that the ordering schemes BPDO and FPDO have different performance for the PMS with different phase combinational logic, which is not identified by any related work [4]–[5][8].
Reference [5] finds that PDO can generate correct PMS BDD only given that the variables are ordered by BPDO or FPDO schemes.

To allow a concatenation scheme or other arbitrary ordering schemes to be used, a two-phase PMS BDD generation algorithm is presented in [5], which firstly uses PDO to deal with some dependencies, and then uses a recursive removal process to deal with all residual dependencies leading to the correct final PMS BDD.
Because the ordering schemes and BDD generation algorithms developed in [3], [5] are widely used in the research work on generalized PMS, our results can also be integrated into new research work.

Due to the dynamic behavior & the statistical dependencies, generalized phased-mission systems offer big challenges in reliability modeling & analysis. A new family of decision diagrams called ternary decision diagrams (TDD) is proposed for use in the resulting separable approach to the GPMS reliability evaluation. Compared with existing methods, the accuracy of ...

context.text: Over the past decade, researchers have proposed a set of new algorithms based on binary decision diagrams (BDD) for fault tree analysis of a wide range of PMS with various mission requirements, and failure behaviors [3]–[6][8].

When the backward PDO scheme (which is the preferred scheme in most related work [4]–[6][8]) is adopted, a special BDD operation can be used to deal with all the dependencies across the phases during the PMS BDD generation, and the PMS BDD evaluation is simple because all dependent variables are placed together.

In this section, we try to show that the ordering schemes BPDO and FPDO have different performance for the PMS with different phase combinational logic, which is not identified by any related work [4]–[6][8].

links.abstract: This paper proposes a new algorithm (DEP-BDD) based on binary decision diagram (BDD) for reliability analysis of phased-mission systems (PMS) with multimode failures. DEP-BDD is a BDD-based combinatorial model which can be used to deal with more than one kind of dependences by applying dependence algebra, which is a generalization of phase algebra that handles more complex dependences. The nature of the BDD contributes the efficiency and low computational complexity of this algorithm. Two exampl...

context.text: Over the past decade, researchers have proposed a set of new algorithms based on binary decision diagrams (BDD) for fault tree analysis of a wide range of PMS with various mission requirements, and failure behaviors [3]–[7][8].

When the backward PDO scheme (which is the preferred scheme in most related work [4]–[7][8]) is adopted, a special BDD operation can be used to deal with all the dependencies across the phases during the PMS BDD generation, and the PMS BDD evaluation is simple because all dependent variables are placed together.

In this section, we try to show that the ordering schemes BPDO and FPDO have different performance for the PMS with different phase combinational logic, which is not identified by any related work [4]–[7][8].
For another example, to analyse the reliability of a PMS with MMF, [7] proposes a set of dependence algebra, and develops a new analysis algorithm based on DEP-BDD, a special kind of BDD.

links.abstract: This paper proposes efficient methods to assess the reliability of phased-mission systems (PMS) considering both imperfect fault coverage (IPC), and common-cause failures (CCF). The IPC introduces multimode failures that must be considered in the accurate reliability analysis of PMS. Another difficulty in analysis is to allow for multiple CCF that can affect different subsets of system components, and which can occur s-dependently. Our methodology for resolving the above difficulties is to separ...

context.text: Over the past decade, researchers have proposed a set of new algorithms based on binary decision diagrams (BDD) for fault tree analysis of a wide range of PMS with various mission requirements, and failure behaviors [3]–[8].

When the backward PDO scheme (which is the preferred scheme in most related work [4]–[8]) is adopted, a special BDD operation can be used to deal with all the dependencies across the phases during the PMS BDD generation, and the PMS BDD evaluation is simple because all dependent variables are placed together.

In this section, we try to show that the ordering schemes BPDO and FPDO have different performance for the PMS with different phase combinational logic, which is not identified by any related work [4]–[8].

For example, to analyse the reliability of a PMS with both IPC and CCF, reference [8] proposes to decompose the original problem into a number of reduced PMS reliability problems that are free from the concern of both IPC, and CCF.

systems with imperfect fault coverage and common-cause failures
references.text: L Xing, "Reliability evaluation of phased-mission systems with imperfect fault coverage and common-cause failures", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 56, pp. 58-68, 2007.

links.abstract: Ordered binary decision diagrams are a useful representation of Boolean functions, if a good variable ordering is known. Variable orderings are computed by heuristic algorithms and then improved with local search and simulated annealing algorithms. This approach is based on the conjecture that the following problem is NP-complete. Given an OBDD G representing f and a size bound s, does there exist an OBDD G* (respecting an arbitrary variable ordering) representing f with at most s nodes? This co...

context.text: But the problem of computing an ordering that minimizes the size of the BDD is itself a NP-Complete problem [9].

of OBDDs is NP-complete
references.text: B. Bollig, I. Wegener, "Improving the variable ordering of OBDDs is NP-complete", IEEE Trans. Computers, vol. 45, no. 9, pp. 993-1002, 1996.

links.abstract: In this paper we present a new data structure for representing Boolean functions and an associated set of manipulation algorithms. Functions are represented by directed, acyclic graphs in a manner similar to the representations introduced by Lee [1] and Akers [2], but with further restrictions on the ordering of decision variables in the graph. Although a function requires, in the worst case, a graph of size exponential in the number of arguments, many of the functions encountered in typical app...

context.text: Applying the two-phase generation algorithm in real PMS instances, we find that it needs large amounts of storage and computation time because it cannot use Bryant's reduction algorithm [10] on-the-fly during the system BDD generation process.
The basic definition for a BDD (also known as function graph) is given in [10].

references.title:

Boolean function manipulation
references.text: R. Bryant, "Graph based algorithms for Boolean function manipulation", IEEE Trans. Computers, vol. C-35, no. 8, pp. 677-691, 1986.

links.abstract: Multiple-Phased Systems (MPS), i.e., systems whose operational life can be partitioned in a set of disjoint periods, called "phases", include several classes of systems such as Phased Mission Systems and Scheduled Maintenance Systems. Because of their deployment in critical applications, the dependability modeling and analysis of Multiple-Phased Systems is a task of primary relevance. The phased behavior makes the analysis of Multiple-Phased Systems extremely complex. This paper describes the mo...

context.text: As stated in [11], PMS are very general because their phases can be characterized along a wide variety of differentiating features: 1) Tasks executed in a phase may differ from those performed within other phases. 2) Performance & dependability requirements can differ from one phase to another. 3) During some phases, the system may be subject to a particularly stressing environment, thus experiencing dramatic increases in the failure rate of its components. 4) The configuration may change over time, in accordance with performance & dependability requirements of the phase being currently executed. 5) The successful completion of a phase may bring a different benefit to the PMS with respect to that obtained with other phases.

references.text: A. Bondavalli, S. Chiaradonna, F. D. Giandomenico, I. Mura, "Dependability modeling and evaluation of multiple-phased systems using DEEM", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 53, no. 4, pp. 509-522, 2004.

links.abstract: Recently, Z. Tang, and J. B. Dugan proposed a new algorithm (DEP-BDD) based on binary decision diagrams (BDD) for reliability analysis of phased-mission systems (PMS) with multimode failures. Although the variable ordering is very important from a practical point of view, it has not been treated directly. This paper develops four ordering heuristics for DEP-BDD based on two ordinary schemes, and evaluates these schemes & heuristics with hundreds of randomly generated fault trees having diffe...

context.text: To illustrate the idea of CPR, a 5-phase PMS designed for data gathering for a scientific experiment can be used, which is borrowed from [12].

Formally, FPDO and BPDO variable ordering can be generated by a two-step method [12], as follows: 1) generate component-level ordering by applying ordinary heuristics to the PMS fault tree in “don't care” form, where phase indexes are omitted. 2) replace each raw component variable by a set of phase-index-attached variables that represent this component in each phase in phase order, or the reverse.

Formally, FCON, and BCON variable ordering can be generated by a two-step method: 1) generate phase ordering by applying ordinary heuristics, such as the one used in [12], to each phase-level fault tree; then 2) concatenate all phase orderings in phase order, or the reverse.

references.title:

BDD analysis of phased-mission systems with multimode failures
references.text: Y. Mo, "Variable ordering to improve BDD analysis of phased-mission systems with multimode failures", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 58, no. 1, pp. 53-57, 2009.
